Chapter on Afflictions, Part 2 of Section on Non-Questions: What is meant by internal accumulation?

If one is defiled by desire towards internal dharmas, not increasing desire, hoping, hoping more, ultimate hoping, difficult to be content, difficult to be satisfied, greed, leaking, drowning in the net of branches, arising from the root, longing, attached to the house of thirst, enduring the pain of love, this is called internal accumulation.
What is meant by external accumulation?
If one is defiled by desire towards external dharmas, up to the pain of love, this is called external accumulation.
What is meant by internal and external accumulation?
If one is defiled by desire towards internal and external dharmas, up to the pain of love, this is called internal and external accumulation.
What is meant by hoping?
If one has good dharmas and hopes, wanting others to know, this is called hoping.
What is meant by great hoping?
If there is much hope, it is called great hope.
What is called evil hope?
If one has no good dharmas oneself but hopes to make others know that one has good [dharmas], this is called evil hope.
What is called craving?
If, regarding one's own wealth, property, wife, children, etc., one craves, is defiled by desire, and clings to them, this is called craving.
What is called evil craving?
If, regarding the wealth, property, wife, children, etc. of others, one wishes to possess them, craves, is defiled by desire, and clings to them, this is called evil craving.
What is called defiled desire?
If one engages in defiled sexual activity with one's mother, teacher's wife, etc., this is called defiled desire.
What are called the three unwholesome roots?
The unwholesome roots of craving, anger, and delusion are called the three unwholesome roots.
What are called the three difficult to subdue?
Desire is difficult to subdue, anger is difficult to subdue, and delusion is difficult to subdue. These are called the three difficult to subdue.

What are the seven kinds of pride?
Pride, pride of inferiority, pride of superiority, pride of conceit, pride of self, wrong pride, and pride within pride.
What is meant by pride?
If I am superior, to be arrogant towards them in one's mind, this is called pride.
What is meant by pride of inferiority?
If they are inferior, to be arrogant towards them in one's mind, this is called pride of inferiority.
What is meant by pride of superiority?
To be arrogant towards them in one's mind, thinking that I am equal to the superior, this is called pride of superiority.
What is meant by pride of conceit?
To be arrogant towards them in one's mind, thinking that one has attained what one has not attained, this is called pride of conceit.
What is meant by pride of self?
To be arrogant towards them in one's mind, thinking that I have good dharmas, this is called pride of self.
What is meant by wrong pride?
If there is no good dharma, and the mind is arrogant towards it, this is called wrong pride.
What is called middling pride?
If one sees the pride of others and gives rise to a mind of pride towards them, this is called middling pride.
Furthermore, self-pride, if there is a body, the mind gives rise to arrogance towards it, this is called self-pride.
Furthermore, wrong pride, if there is wrong view, the mind gives rise to arrogance towards it, this is called wrong pride.
Furthermore, middling pride, if I am superior among the superior, noble among the noble, the mind gives rise to arrogance towards them, this is called middling pride.
These are called the seven kinds of pride.

What are the seven kinds of outflows?
The seven kinds of leakage are: leakage of views, leakage of patience, leakage of intimacy, leakage of separation, leakage of subduing, leakage of precepts, and leakage of contemplation.
What are the seven weak dharmas?
Killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and frivolous speech - these are called the seven weak dharmas.
What are the seven movements?

I will have, I will not have, I will have form, I will not have form, I will have the thought of self, I will not have the thought of self, I will have neither the thought of existence nor the thought of nonexistence - these are called the seven movements.
The seven kinds of self-conceit, seven kinds of seeking, seven kinds of perversity, seven kinds of actions, and seven kinds of birth are also like this.
What are the eight worldly dharmas?
Gain, loss, slander, praise, fame, disgrace, suffering, and pleasure - these are called the eight worldly dharmas.
What are the eight kinds of non-noble speech?

If one says one has seen when one has not seen, says one has not seen when one has seen, says one has heard when one has not heard, says one has not heard when one has heard, says one has sensed when one has not sensed, says one has not sensed when one has sensed, says one has cognized when one has not cognized, says one has not cognized when one has cognized, these are called the eight unwholesome ways of speech.

What are the eight difficult circumstances that hinder the practice of pure conduct?

There is a Buddha who appears in the world, a TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Trainer of Those to Be Tamed, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One, who expounds the Dharma of tranquil extinction, the abandonment of desires, and the path leading to nirvana. Yet there are sentient beings dwelling in the hells. This is called the first difficult condition that obstructs the practice of pure conduct.

Furthermore, a Buddha appears in the world, a TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Trainer of Those to Be Tamed, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One, who expounds the Dharma of tranquil extinction, the abandonment of desires, and the path leading to nirvana. Yet there are sentient beings dwelling in the animal realm, the realm of hungry ghosts, the long-lived heavens, in border regions inhabited by ignorant people, or in places not reached by monks, nuns, laymen, or laywomen. This is called up to the fifth difficult condition that obstructs the practice of pure conduct.

Furthermore, when a Buddha appears in the world, the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One teaches the Dharma of tranquility and detachment, the path leading to the attainment of nirvana. Some beings are born in the same country, yet they have wrong views and inverted views.
Due to the ripening of the fruits of wrong views and inverted views, they end up in hell. This is called the sixth difficult condition that obstructs the practice of pure conduct.

Furthermore, when a Buddha appears in the world, the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One teaches the Dharma of tranquility, cessation, and detachment, the path leading to the attainment of nirvana. Some beings are born in the same country, yet they are deaf, blind, mute, and dumb like sheep, unable to understand the karmic retributions of good and evil deeds. This is called the seventh difficult condition that obstructs the practice of pure conduct.

Furthermore, when the Buddha does not appear in the world, he is not called a Tathagata, up to a World-Honored One, and does not speak of the Dharma of tranquil extinction, detachment from desire, the right path leading to nirvana. This is called the eight difficult circumstances that hinder the practice of pure conduct. The eight dharmas are concluded.
What are the nine kinds of dharmas?

Because of the various elements, various contacts arise. Because of the various contacts, various feelings arise. Because of the various feelings, various perceptions arise. Because of the various perceptions, various thoughts arise. Because of the various thoughts, various desires arise. Because of the various desires, various gains arise. Because of the various gains, various pursuits arise. Because of the various pursuits, various torments arise. These are called the nine kinds of dharmas.
What are the nine fundamental dharmas of craving?

Because of craving, there is seeking; because of seeking, there is gain; because of gain, there is making; because of making, there is desire and passion; because of desire and passion, there is endurance; because of endurance, there is stinginess; because of stinginess, there is hoarding; because of hoarding, there is guarding, injuring, beating, binding, and quarreling. These are called the nine roots of craving.
What are the nine abodes of beings?
There are beings with various bodies and various perceptions, such as humans and gods in the desire realm. This is called the first abode of beings.

There are sentient beings without perception or thought, namely the non-percipient devas, this is called the fifth abode of sentient beings.
There are sentient beings in the sphere of infinite space, this is called the sixth abode of sentient beings.
There are sentient beings in the sphere of infinite consciousness, this is called the seventh abode of sentient beings.
There are sentient beings in the sphere of nothingness, this is called the eighth abode of sentient beings.
There are sentient beings in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, this is called the ninth abode of sentient beings.
What are the nine disadvantages of violating the precepts?

Regret, displeasure, unhappiness, non-elimination, mental suffering, distraction, not knowing and seeing as they are, not understanding, not skillful, these are called the nine disadvantages of violating the precepts. The nine dharmas are concluded.
